text.tspan: Show, Don't Tell

text.data-name: Only a little over half of Arcane use Dialogue
text.tspan: Only a little over half of Arcane use Dialogue
Welcome to the Playground
The Monster You Created
vs

text.data-name:
Arcane takes the golden rule of writing —Show, Don't Tell— very seriously, putting a lot of work into telling the story visually and letting the plot unfold and its characters develop, right in front of our eyes, with no more words than needed.
The chart
text.tspan: Arcane takes the golden rule of writing —Show, Don't Tell— very seriously, putting a lot of
work into telling the story visually and letting the plot unfold and its characters develop,
right in front of our eyes, with no more words than needed.
The chart analyzes Arcane's first and last episode transcripts, breaking down the different
lines from Netflix subtitles into dialogue and non-dialogue lines. One major drawback of
using the transcripts as opposite to the screenplay is that I can't count for action lines,
rather we are limited to audibles. Still, it gives us a good idea of the Show's use of the Show
Don't Tell rule. The no-dialogue section is broken down further into pure SFX and lyrics
lines.
Almost half of the show is told without the use of dialogues, with dialogue-free lines making
up for 45% and 41% of Welcome to the Playground and The Monster You Created entire
transcript lines, respectively. The Monster you created has a higher percentage of dialogue
lines at 59% compared to 55% for Welcome to the Playground; it is to note, however, that
since the latter is a few minutes longer, The Monster You Created actually has less overall
dialogue lines at 315, that is sixty four lines behind Welcome to the Playground.
Welcome to the Playground appears to have twice as many lyrics lines compared to the
finale, duo to it having both intro and outro songs. The finale, on the other hand, only has
an intro song as it cuts into a long end credits scene right after Jinx sets out the explosion to
the council very seriously.
Show, Don't Tell
The golden rule of writing
